hero.title: GLORYFIT
hero.subtitle: Personalized routines from your data
hero.description: We designed a mobile experience that transforms biometric data into adapted, accessible, and motivating routines. The goal was clear: generate enough trust for users to share sensitive information in exchange for recommendations that truly impact their health.

myRole.title: My role
myRole.description: My specific contribution: ‚Ä¢ Qualitative research on barriers to biometric data entry. ‚Ä¢ Design of onboarding flow and routine personalization. ‚Ä¢ Construction of the complete visual system. ‚Ä¢ Functional prototyping in Figma for Android, validated with real users.

challenge.title: The challenge
challenge.text1: GloryFit came pre-installed on the Q18 smartwatch, an affordable wearable targeting a broad audience. Its promise: track steps, heart rate, sleep, and provide basic training routines.
challenge.text2: But in practice, the problems became evident. The interface felt arbitrary, onboarding was chaotic, and routines were generic. There was no experience that truly connected with users.
challenge.text3: From the start, our focus was to rethink this logic: how do we build an experience that invites rather than imposes?

research.title: Research and discovery
research.text1: We began by mapping friction points in existing fitness apps. We conducted user interviews, data privacy surveys, and benchmarked platforms like Google Fit, Zepp, and MiFitness.
research.text2: A clear pattern emerged: users were willing to share biometric data only when they perceived immediate value‚Äînot at the end of onboarding, but in the moment.

strategy.title: Design strategy
strategy.text1: We made a key decision: demonstrate value before collecting data. The flow needed to be progressive without being slow, simple without being superficial.
strategy.text2: We structured the experience around two key moments:
strategy.moment1: First, gradual and justified information entry. We only asked for essentials upfront: age, activity level, and goals.
strategy.moment2: Second, immediate visible personalization. Once users completed the basics, they instantly accessed the "My Routine" module.

system.title: The system behind it
system.text1: We designed a personalization system that combined age, activity level, medical history, and goals.
examples: A sedentary user over 40 received a progressive, low-impact routine.
An active user without injuries got a medium-to-high intensity routine.
Users with injury history were shown low-risk exercises first.
system.text2: We also built an algorithmic transparency module‚Äîeach recommendation could display its underlying logic.

experience.title: Experience design
experience.text1: The experience needed to convey clarity, control, and wellness‚Äînot glamour or "extreme fitness."
components: Segmented buttons for activity level and time selection
Persistent FAB for quick routine access
experience.visualSystemText: Soft greens as the primary color, neutral grays for information hierarchy, and Roboto typography for optimal Android readability.

iterations.title: Iterations and validation
iterations.text1: During initial testing, we identified a critical issue: asking for sensitive data too early caused users to abandon the flow.
iterations.text2: We solved this by reordering: first show a preliminary routine, then request sensitive data to refine it.
iterations.result: The result? More complete onboarding with a stronger sense of security and user control.

learnings.title: Timing matters as much as the data itself.
learnings.text: When you ask for information directly impacts abandonment rates.

learnings.title: Transparency beats automation.
learnings.text: Users prefer understanding why something is recommended over black-box suggestions.

learnings.title: Control builds trust.
learnings.text: Allowing users to adjust their routines strengthens their sense of ownership and security.

learnings.title: Clarity resonates with 35+ users.
learnings.text: This demographic rejects visually cluttered or overwhelming experiences.

validation.title: Validation and feedback
validation.text: We validated with our target demographic: adults 35-55 looking to rebuild their fitness habits.

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.subtitle: GloryFit taught us a powerful lesson:
conclusion.text: Trust isn't earned through polished visuals‚Äîit's built through interactions that deliver real value, respect user pace, and clearly explain their purpose.

hero.title: D√çGITO
hero.subtitle: Operations Module
hero.description: UX/UI redesign of D√≠gito's operations module: I transformed time tracking from a forgotten chore into a natural part of daily workflow.

myRole.title: My role
myRole.description: Research & synthesis ‚Ä¢ Strategy & architecture ‚Ä¢ Design & prototyping ‚Ä¢ Testing & validation

context.title: Context
context.text1: D√≠gito is a Business Intelligence and RPA company. Their B2B SaaS platform handled billing, reports, and administration‚Äîbut the operations module for consultants suffered from low adoption.
context.text2: The goal was clear: integrate time tracking naturally into workflow, not as an additional burden.

problem.title: Initial hypothesis vs. reality
problem.criticalQuestion: Critical question: Are users forgetting, or actively avoiding?
problem.problemTitle: The real problem: hours logged 1-3 weeks late
problem.scopeText: No changes to contracts, organizational processes, or core infrastructure.

research.title: Research: the real problem isn't forgetting‚Äîit's active deprioritization
research.subtitle: I combined desk research, user interviews, and MVP auditing.

deskResearch.title: Desk Research
deskResearch.text: Validated behavioral patterns through productivity literature.
deskResearch.theory: Theoretical backing: Users avoid processes requiring excessive cognitive overhead.
deskResearch.benchmark: Industry benchmark: 60% of employees view time tracking as surveillance.

audit.title: MVP heuristic audit
audit.text: Identified fragmented flows, admin-centered interface, and permanent cognitive load.

research.quotesTitle: Quotes that revealed the real problem

perception.label: System perception:
perception.text: "On a scale of 1 to 10, I see it more as a 1: administrative control."

postponement.label: Active postponement:
postponement.text1: "If an emergency comes up, tracking is left for later."
postponement.text2: "I do it at the end of the day, where I log everything at once."

friction.label: Physical friction:
friction.text: "If I close my laptop, it's annoying to turn it back on just to log."

dependencies.label: Operational dependencies:
dependencies.text: "If the CEO doesn't review that day, approval gets paused."

insight.title: Core insight
insight.mainText: Tracking isn't happening because it adds no value to actual work.
insight.explanation: The system was built around data collection, not user action.
insight.pivotFrom: From: "How do we make people remember to log hours?"
insight.pivotTo: To: "How do we make tracking a natural byproduct of work?"

strategy.title: Strategy: operations module, not complete overhaul
strategy.text: After analyzing insights, it became clear that improving tracking didn't require redesigning the entire platform.
strategy.alternativeTitle: Business alternative considered: penalize late entries
strategy.alternativeText: The business team proposed: enforce tracking through penalties.
strategy.conclusion: Conclusion: The sustainable path is making tracking fast, useful, and seamlessly integrated.
strategy.scopeText1: The original brief covered 8 improvement areas. Redesigning the entire platform was infeasible within 3.5 months.
strategy.ourDecisionText: Focus where consultants track time, manage tasks, and monitor workload.
strategy.whyNotJustScope: Why this wasn't just scope reduction:
strategy.whyNotJustScopeText: Research confirmed consultants had no issues with billing or management reporting‚Äîthe pain was in daily operations.

principles.title: Design principles
principles.subtitle: Build a tool, not a burden.

differentiation.title: Differentiation:
differentiation.text: Be an operational tool, not just a time logger.

technicalViability.title: Technical viability:
technicalViability.text: Integrate with existing MVP without a full rewrite.

principles.guidingPrinciple: Build a tool, not a burden.

frictions.title: 5 critical frictions & design decisions
frictions.subtitle: Each friction point mapped directly to a design solution.

friction1.title: Friction: Tracking feels like extra work
friction1.pain: User quote: "I forget to log hours because I'm focused on actual work."
friction1.decision: Solution: Embed tracking into daily workflow.
friction1.whyWorks: Impact: Reduces cognitive load through contextual, proactive prompts.
friction1.translatedTo: Implementation: FAB with smart suggestions and autocomplete.

friction2.title: Friction: No visibility into why tracking matters
friction2.pain: User quote: "I don't see the point‚Äîit's just for billing."
friction2.decision: Solution: Surface real-time impact of tracking.
whyWorks: Creates sense of purpose and team connection.
friction2.translatedTo: Implementation: Dashboard with personal and team analytics.

friction3.title: Friction: System is rigid, can't handle interruptions
friction3.pain: User quote: "When an emergency hits, the system slows me down."
friction3.decision: Solution: Make tracking flexible and fast.
friction3.whyWorks: Impact: Adapts to real work patterns, not idealized ones.
friction3.translatedTo: Implementation: Quick-log with shortcuts and bulk edit.

friction4.title: Friction: Too many clicks required
friction4.pain: User quote: "It takes too many clicks just to log one hour."
friction4.decision: Solution: Streamline interface and minimize steps.
friction4.whyWorks: Impact: Reduces time tax on administrative tasks.
friction4.translatedTo: Implementation: Minimal UI, intuitive navigation patterns.

friction5.title: Friction: Feels like surveillance, not a tool
friction5.pain: User quote: "The system controls me instead of helping me."
friction5.decision: Solution: Give consultants autonomy and control.
friction5.whyWorks: Impact: Shifts perception from oversight to empowerment.

architecture.title: Solution architecture: 3 core pillars
architecture.subtitle: The solution centers on three interconnected design pillars.

unifiedPanel.title: Unified Hub: Autonomy & Visibility
unifiedPanel.problem: Consultants juggle multiple tools to manage work.
unifiedPanel.solution: One centralized dashboard integrating tasks, projects, and time tracking.
unifiedPanel.syncText: All data updates instantly across views.

automation.title: Smart Assistance: Speed & Context
automation.problem: Manual time tracking is tedious and constantly delayed.
automation.solution: Intelligent tracking that adapts to user behavior.

social.title: Transparency Layer: Trust & Value
social.problem: Tracking feels like surveillance, not support.
social.result: Shifts perception from oversight tool to value driver.

dashboard.title: Refined Dashboard
dashboard.subtitle: Consultant's operations center
dashboard.text: A panel that unifies all relevant information.

testing.title: User testing & validation
testing.subtitle: Moderated usability testing with D√≠gito consultants.
testing.participants: 4 consultants: PM, Developer, UX Designer, Analyst.
testing.objective: Validate ease of use and identify friction points.

friction1.title: Issue 1: Can't find archived projects
friction1.text: Users needed to access project history, but the filter was buried.

friction2.title: Issue 2: Unclear task states
friction2.text: Visual distinction between "in progress" and "pending" was ambiguous.

iteration2.title: Fix 2: Clear state indicators
iteration2.learning: Visual clarity directly reduces cognitive load.

qualitative.title: Qualitative shift:
qualitative.afterQuote: "It's actually fast now. The suggestions save me time."
qualitative.impactText: From administrative burden to productivity tool.

learnings.title: Key takeaways:
learnings.subtitle: Design is strategy, not decoration.
learnings.text1: The breakthrough was reframing the problem from "forgetting" to "active avoidance."
learnings.text2: Effective design addresses both business goals and user needs.
learnings.learning: Good design is invisible. Great design empowers.
learnings.text3: Early user validation prevents expensive pivots.

aiEvolution.title: Future roadmap: AI integration
aiEvolution.note: AI augments humans, it doesn't replace them.

onboarding.title: Phase 1: Onboarding and personalization
onboarding.note: Effective onboarding is key to retention.

mobile.title: Phase 2: Mobile experience
mobile.text1: Develop a mobile version of the operations module.
mobile.text2: The goal is for consultants to manage their time from anywhere.
mobile.note: Mobility is essential for modern productivity.

items.title: Context:
items.text: Use location and time data for suggestions.

gridLearnings.title: Design is discovery, not decoration.
gridLearnings.text: Initial hypotheses rarely match the real problem.

gridLearnings.title: Empathy unlocks better solutions.
gridLearnings.text: Deep understanding of user pain points reveals the path forward.

gridLearnings.title: Iteration beats perfection.
gridLearnings.text: Each round of feedback compounds improvements.

gridLearnings.title: Impact lives in stories and metrics.

closing.title: Final thoughts
closing.text1: D√≠gito reinforced that product design transcends aesthetics.
closing.text2: The real challenge was reframing "surveillance" as "empowerment."
closing.highlight: Design bridges the gap between problems and solutions.

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.subtitle: D√≠gito proved that thoughtful design shifts perception:
conclusion.text: From time-tracking burden to productivity catalyst.

hero.title: LEVEL UP
hero.subtitle: Redesigning gaming editorial for Latin America
hero.description: I transformed a generic gaming news site into a personalized, region-aware experience for Latin American audiences.

myRole.title: My role
myRole.description: Regional preference research ‚Ä¢ Personalization system design ‚Ä¢ Geosegmentation strategy ‚Ä¢ Scalable interface design

challenge.title: The challenge
challenge.text1: Transform a one-size-fits-all news portal into something personally relevant.
challenge.text2: The key challenge: honor regional gaming preferences without fragmenting the experience.

problem.title: The problem
problem.text: One editorial view fits nobody well. Level Up published 20+ stories daily with no filtering or personalization.
problem.quote: "I'm on PlayStation, so Xbox and Nintendo news just clutter my feed. I get lost in the noise."

insight.title: Strategic insight
insight.text: Gaming preferences cluster by region: Mexico favors Xbox, Argentina leans PlayStation/PC.
insight.proposal: Build an editorial experience that adapts to both preference and location.

vision.title: System Vision
vision.text: I projected an active + passive segmentation solution:

active.title: Active segmentation (roadmap):
active.text: Geolocation API integration for regional content.

finalVersion.title: The final implemented version
items: Clean aesthetic, dark mode, red accent

learnings.title: Personalization should feel gradual, not invasive.
learnings.text: Users opt in when they see immediate value.

learnings.title: Regional differences are actionable design data.
Editorial UX must respect business needs.
learnings.text: Monetization and experience coexist or both fail.

learnings.title: Timing matters when requesting preferences.
learnings.text: Demonstrate value first, then ask for data.

reflection.title: Final reflection
reflection.text: This wasn't just a redesign‚Äîit was a strategic framework for how editorial platforms can scale while staying personally relevant.

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.subtitle: LevelUp showed that smart editorial personalization delivers:
conclusion.text: Combining regional intelligence, user preferences, and thoughtful design creates genuinely useful editorial experiences.

hero.title: VORTERIX
hero.subtitle: Paren la mano - Landing Page
hero.description: A no-nonsense landing page. Designed to hook attention and convert casual listeners into community‚Äîin under 10 seconds.

brief.title: The real brief: constraints as design fuel
brief.quote: "Convert listeners to leads. No metrics. No data. Just smart decisions that work."
brief.description: Academic project, professional execution. Goal: capture young audiences through exclusive content.

why.title: Why this landing existed
reasons: Vorterix's main site didn't match Paren la Mano's vibe.
Young fans engaged on Twitch but never converted.
Exclusive content existed but had no clear discovery path.
The main site lacked CTAs and narrative pull.

audience.title: Design starts with understanding them
audience.description: We analyzed the show's tone, social media patterns, and studied what worked for peers like Olga and LuzuTV.
wants: Give value upfront, not empty promises.

persona.text: We didn't design for a general audience. We designed for Agust√≠n, who listens to Twitch while editing in Premiere.

decisions.title: Clips carousel:
decisions.text: shows value before asking for email.

iterations.title: Key iterations
items: Redesigned clips section 3x for mobile responsiveness.
Debated: highlight hosts or showcase content?
iterations.resolution: Content won. Communities form around value, not personalities.
iterations.learning: These choices didn't make the prettiest version‚Äîthey made the version that converted.

ux.title: UX without narrative is just decoration
ux.text: I learned: without real content, design is theater. Without narrative structure, conversion is luck.

conclusion.title: What this really was
conclusion.text1: A lab for decision-making under constraints: design, narrative, content, technical limits.
conclusion.text2: I confirmed: constraints don't limit creativity‚Äîthey sharpen judgment. And that's what I love most about design.

hero.title: RECTO FINAL
hero.subtitle: Physical-digital game where the only way out... is through
hero.description: UNLP academic project fusing Unity 2D with hacked hardware to create a resilient, immersive installation.

myRole.title: My role
myRole.description: Lead programmer (Unity 2D + C#) ‚Ä¢ Hardware integration ‚Ä¢ Co-creative director & narrative design

context.title: Project context
context.brief: The brief was unforgiving: build a physical-digital game that survives hours of public use without constant tech support.

specs.title: Technical specs
specs.engine: Unity 2D with custom input handling ‚Ä¢ C#
specs.hardware: Modded PC steering wheel + hacked keyboard + arcade buttons

challenge.title: The real challenge
challenge.subtitle: Build an installation that survives 3+ hours of public use without breaking
challenge.elements: Mandatory elements: Pirate + dimetrodon + rusty hammer + ecofuturism.
challenge.decision: Key decision: Don't fight the absurd‚Äîembrace it and make it viscerally coherent.

narrative.title: Making absurdity coherent
narrative.solution: El Pelusa, a pirate, gets swallowed by a dimetrodon. From inside the dinosaur's stomach, he defends his ship by smashing pirate skeletons.
narrative.twist: The punchline: The "light at the end of the tunnel" is literally the digestive exit. Hence Recto Final.

mechanics.title: From concept to code: physical mechanics
mechanics.description: Hybrid of Whac-A-Mole + Subway Surfers, but with real hardware:
items: Hittable skulls: hacked keyboard with embedded buttons
Steering wheel: modded PC wheel for navigation
Auto-flow: Start ‚Üí Intro ‚Üí Tutorial ‚Üí Game ‚Üí Game Over ‚Üí Loop

technical.title: Critical technical calls
technical.responsibility: My responsibility: full Unity game system programming
items: Lives & escalating waves with responsive HUD
Zero-button flow: hit to start immediately
technical.goal: One goal: the system should be self-explanatory.

tension.title: Real crisis moments
incidents: Day before launch: wheel started drifting right.
7-year-old smashed the hammer so hard it broke.
tension.resolution: I rewrote input handling to accept direct hand hits. Players never noticed the switch.

resistance.title: System resilience
metrics: Strong visual appeal created spontaneous queues
resistance.learning: It wasn't the fanciest tech‚Äîit was the most resilient. In real-world conditions, that's what matters.

learnings.title: The best systems survive, not just impress.
learnings.text: Elegant tech fails if it can't handle enthusiastic kids.

learnings.title: Absurd constraints demand narrative engineering.
learnings.text: The humor was a design constraint, not a bug.

learnings.title: Leading under pressure means keeping it playable.
The best tech disappears.
learnings.text: Success is measured by visceral player connection.

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.subtitle: Recto Final proved creative engineering can tame chaos:
conclusion.text: Robust code + hacked hardware + absurd narrative = experiences that survive real-world conditions.
